key_work.title: How to Sell to Australia
key_work.brief_description: Since the beginning of television, Australian advertising has embedded itself into the national psyche through harnessing the moving image. Advertisers haven’t just sold products to Australian audiences, they’ve also built community, spread iconic catchphrases and created beloved characters.

start.title: Anti-tobacco advertising
start.brief_description: In 1968, a cigarette ad ran every 14 minutes on Australian TV. Cancer Council Victoria director Nigel Gray responded with a star-studded anti-tobacco campaign launched in 1971, which became the foundation for boundary-pushing anti-smoking filmmaking in Australia. These ads became part of our collective consciousness and their messages continue to inspire people to quit.

links.description: The Anti-Cancer Council also used star power. Warren Mitchell was a huge star in the 1960s, famous for playing bigoted cockney Alf Garnett in the BBC sitcom Till Death Do Us Part and the Anti-Cancer Council harnessed his abrasive charisma in a series of anti-smoking ads.

links.description: Betty White knows the power of advertising, especially during a US Super Bowl. Her appearance in the 2010 Snickers commercial re-launched the then 88-year old’s career leading to an Emmy-winning hosting gig on Saturday Night Live and a role on sitcom Hot in Cleveland.

links.description: Cementing Super Bowl advertising as marketing gold garnering as much attention as the game itself, Apple’s “1984”, almost didn’t go to air. While hated by the board of directors and the then CEO, Apple went ahead with the Ridley Scott directed commercial which was quickly hailed as a masterstroke.

links.description: David Lynch’s “Welcome to the Third Place” for the launch of Play Station 2 sits somewhere between Twin Peaks and Eraserhead. Based on the premise that the console was a gateway to a mysterious otherworld, Sony had certainly hired the right director for the task.
